elements.content: Three CuII helical complexes, [Cu(H2O)4(dpa)] n (1), [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n (2), and [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n (3) (H2dpa = diphenic acid, 4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine, and dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene), have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystal structure determination. 1 is a one-dimensional helical chain of pseudo square-planar Cu(H2O)4 bridged by bis-monodentate dpa. The hydrogen-bonding interactions extend the helical chain forming a two-dimensional layer structure. 2 and 3 are three-dimensional coordination polymers composed of Cu−dpa helical chains bridged by 4,4‘-bipy and dpe, respectively. The longer spacer between coordination sites in dpe results in a 2-fold-interpenetration of the three-dimensional framework in 3. The helical pitches in 1−3 are 7.632, 11.425, and 16.022 Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Three CuII helical complexes, [Cu(H2O)4(dpa)] n  (1), [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n  (2), and [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n  (3) (H2dpa = diphenic acid, 4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine, and dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene), have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystal structure determination. 1 is a one-dimensional helical chain of pseudo square-planar Cu(H2O)4 bridged by bis-monodentate dpa. The hydrogen-bonding interactions extend the helical chain forming a two-dimensional layer structure. 2 and 3 are three-dimensional coordination polymers composed of Cu-dpa helical chains bridged by 4,4‘-bipy and dpe, respectively. The longer spacer between coordination sites in dpe results in a 2-fold-interpenetration of the three-dimensional framework in 3. The helical pitches in 1-3 are 7.632, 11.425, and 16.022 Å, respectively.

elements.content: Three copper(II) helical complexes comprising discrete helical chains, [Cu(H2O)4(dpa)] n (1), [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n (2), and [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n (3) (H2dpa = diphenic acid, 4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine and dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene), have been synthesized and characterized. The helical pitches in 1−3 are 7.632, 11.425 and 16.022 Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Three copper(II) helical complexes comprising discrete helical chains, [Cu(H2O)4(dpa)] n  (1), [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n  (2), and [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n  (3) (H2dpa = diphenic acid, 4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine and dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene), have been synthesized and characterized. The helical pitches in 1-3 are 7.632, 11.425 and 16.022 Å, respectively.

elements.content: The designed synthesis and characterization of metal−organic frameworks containing channels and cavities with various sizes and shapes have achieved considerable progress in supramolecular chemistry and material chemistry. The increasing interest in this field is justified not only by their potential application as functional materials, but also by the particular beauty and intriguing structural diversities of the architectures. Much effort has been devoted to controllable formation of desirable one-, two-, and three-dimensional polymers with the concept of rational design and crystal engineering. The selection of multifunctional organic ligands containing appropriate coordination sites linked by a spacer with specific positional orientation is especially crucial to the construction of desirable frameworks. A number of fascinating metal−organic coordination polymers have been formed through using di- or polytopic ligands, especially the rigid neutral donor ligands, such as 4,4‘-bipy, pyrazine, and tri-4-pyridyl-1,3,5-triazine, or anionic ligands, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, as linkers and metal ions or metal cluster as nodes. The combination of metal ions with neutral and anionic mixed bridging ligands not only affords interestingly extended structures and functional properties, but also makes the assembly process more controllable than a single ligand. The prospect of introducing the second or more organic ligands into a reaction system provides further impetus for research on metal−organic supramolecular frameworks. However, due to the presence of many subtle interactions in supramolecular systems as well as difficult prediction of the compositions or structures of the products, the construction of extended solids based on mixed bridging ligands is still at a primitive stage and is still a challenge to chemists despite the fact that a few examples have been reported. Thus, it is of great importance to establish proper synthetic strategies and rules leading to desirable supramolecular systems through controlling the assembly process of mixed bridging ligands and metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The designed synthesis and characterization of metal-organic frameworks containing channels and cavities with various sizes and shapes have achieved considerable progress in supramolecular chemistry and material chemistry. The increasing interest in this field is justified not only by their potential application as functional materials, but also by the particular beauty and intriguing structural diversities of the architectures. Much effort has been devoted to controllable formation of desirable one-, two-, and three-dimensional polymers with the concept of rational design and crystal engineering. The selection of multifunctional organic ligands containing appropriate coordination sites linked by a spacer with specific positional orientation is especially crucial to the construction of desirable frameworks. A number of fascinating metal-organic coordination polymers have been formed through using di- or polytopic ligands, especially the rigid neutral donor ligands, such as 4,4‘-bipy, pyrazine, and tri-4-pyridyl-1,3,5-triazine, or anionic ligands, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, as linkers and metal ions or metal cluster as nodes. The combination of metal ions with neutral and anionic mixed bridging ligands not only affords interestingly extended structures and functional properties, but also makes the assembly process more controllable than a single ligand. The prospect of introducing the second or more organic ligands into a reaction system provides further impetus for research on metal-organic supramolecular frameworks. However, due to the presence of many subtle interactions in supramolecular systems as well as difficult prediction of the compositions or structures of the products, the construction of extended solids based on mixed bridging ligands is still at a primitive stage and is still a challenge to chemists despite the fact that a few examples have been reported. Thus, it is of great importance to establish proper synthetic strategies and rules leading to desirable supramolecular systems through controlling the assembly process of mixed bridging ligands and metal ions.

elements.content: In the construction of coordination frameworks with cavities and channels, diphenic acid (H2dpa) is a useful aromatic dicarboxylate ligand and possesses several interesting structural characterizations. In dpa, two phenyl rings are not coplanar with each other owing to the steric hindrance of 2,2‘-positioned carboxylate groups in the coordination process. The distortion of the diphenyl spacer about the central bond endows dpa a peculiar characterization to link metal ions or metal clusters into macrocycles12 or helical chains. Meantime, the extended structural motifs can be generated through using other bridging ligands to connect these macrocycles or helical chains. Very recently, we have reported a new type of three-dimensional pillared framework [{Cd2(dpa)(pya)}6(pya)6(dpe)3] n constructed from dodecanuclear cadmium(II) macrocycles through introducing 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe) into the reaction system and in situ synthesis of isonicotinate (Hpya = isonicotinic acid). However, no examples of the extended structures comprising helical chains from dpa have been reported to date despite the fact that the helical architectures are the best one for understanding of metal−ligand coding edifices, and the basic features of the designed assembly of helical complexes are now fairly well established. Thus, it will be valuable to construct extended frameworks based on the helical chains. Considering the influence of coordination geometry of metal ions on the solid-state architectures, we have introduced exo-bidentate 4,4‘-bipy and dpe (4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine, dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene) into a Cu−dpa system as the second ligands. Herein, we wish to report the syntheses and characterizations of three helical copper(II) complexes, [Cu(H2O)4(dpa)] n (1), [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n (2), and [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n (3). 2 and 3 have constructed through 4,4‘-bipy and dpe bridge the adjacent Cu−dpa helical chains, respectively.
elements.clean_text: In the construction of coordination frameworks with cavities and channels, diphenic acid (H2dpa) is a useful aromatic dicarboxylate ligand and possesses several interesting structural characterizations. In dpa, two phenyl rings are not coplanar with each other owing to the steric hindrance of 2,2‘-positioned carboxylate groups in the coordination process. The distortion of the diphenyl spacer about the central bond endows dpa a peculiar characterization to link metal ions or metal clusters into macrocycles12 or helical chains. Meantime, the extended structural motifs can be generated through using other bridging ligands to connect these macrocycles or helical chains. Very recently, we have reported a new type of three-dimensional pillared framework [{Cd2(dpa)(pya)}6(pya)6(dpe)3] n  constructed from dodecanuclear cadmium(II) macrocycles through introducing 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe) into the reaction system and in situ synthesis of isonicotinate (Hpya = isonicotinic acid). However, no examples of the extended structures comprising helical chains from dpa have been reported to date despite the fact that the helical architectures are the best one for understanding of metal-ligand coding edifices, and the basic features of the designed assembly of helical complexes are now fairly well established. Thus, it will be valuable to construct extended frameworks based on the helical chains. Considering the influence of coordination geometry of metal ions on the solid-state architectures, we have introduced exo-bidentate 4,4‘-bipy and dpe (4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine, dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene) into a Cu-dpa system as the second ligands. Herein, we wish to report the syntheses and characterizations of three helical copper(II) complexes, [Cu(H2O)4(dpa)] n  (1), [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n  (2), and [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n   (3). 2 and 3 have constructed through 4,4‘-bipy and dpe bridge the adjacent Cu-dpa helical chains, respectively.

elements.content: Diphenic acid, 4,4‘-bipyridine, and 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification, while all the other reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. The IR spectrum as KBr disk was recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer. C, H, and N elemental analyses were determined on an Elementary Vario ELIII elemental analyzer. Thermal Analyses were performed on a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA Instrument and SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA-DTA Instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

Diphenic acid, 4,4‘-bipyridine, and 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification, while all the other reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. The IR spectrum as KBr disk was recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer. C, H, and N elemental analyses were determined on an Elementary Vario ELIII elemental analyzer. Thermal Analyses were performed on a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA Instrument and SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA-DTA Instrument.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu(H 2 O) 4 (dpa)] n (1). A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was added slowly to a stirring solution of H2dpa (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL), and then 1 mol L-1 NaOH aqueous solution was added dropwise to the reaction mixture until a slight amount of precipitate was formed. The precipitate was filtered off, and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for one week; the blue crystals were produced. Yield:  0.09 g (48%). Anal. Calcd. for C14H16CuO8 (375.81):  C, 44.74; H, 4.26%. Found:  C, 44.69; H, 4.28%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3619 (m), 3435 (m), 3180 (w), 1610 (s), 1600 (s), 1578 (s), 1538 (s), 1495 (m), 1472 (m), 1444 (m), 1397 (vs, br), 1367 (s), 1281 (w), 1271 (w), 1243 (w), 1151 (w), 1109 (vw), 1094 (vw), 1049 (vw), 1006 (w), 989 (vw), 958 (vw), 884 (vw), 830 (m), 813 (w), 771 (m), 679 (m), 662 (m), 622 (w), 588 (vw), 574 (w), 476 (w).

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n (2). A mixture of H2dpa (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), and NaOH (0.03 g, 0.75 mmol) with a molar ratio of about 2:2:2:3 in H2O (15.0 mL) was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 160 °C for 72 h, and then the reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 24 h. A larger amount of dark-blue crystals were obtained and collected by filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield:  0.14 g (61%). Anal. Calcd. for C24H16CuN2O4 (459.92):  C, 62.67; H, 3.48; N, 6.09%. Found:  C, 62.63; H, 3.51; N, 6.07%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3440 (vw, br), 1606 (s), 1584 (s), 1560 (m), 1535 (m), 1488 (m), 1403 (vs, br), 1367 (s), 1327 (m), 1220 (w), 1162 (w), 1148 (w), 1107 (vw), 1094 (vw), 1071 (w), 1046 (vw), 1008 (vw), 960 (vw), 853 (vw), 843 (w), 822 (m), 772 (m), 721 (m), 681 (w), 662 (vw), 641 (w), 590 (vw), 556 (w), 485 (w).

A larger amount of dark-blue crystals were obtained and collected by filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 0.14 g (61%). Anal. elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n (3). The procedure is similar to the synthesis of 2 except that dpe (0.09 g, 0.5 mmol) was used instead of 4,4‘-bipy. Yield:  0.18 g (74%). Anal. Calcd. for C26H18CuN2O4 (485.96):  C, 64.26; H, 3.70; N, 5.76%. Found:  C, 64.22; H, 3.71; N, 5.74%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3440 (vw, br), 1610 (s), 1586 (s), 1566 (m), 1556 (m), 1502 (m), 1402 (vs, br), 1347 (s), 1298 (w), 1251 (w), 1219 (w), 1205 (w), 1147 (w), 1102 (vw), 1069 (vw), 1047 (vw), 1025 (w), 987 (w), 969 (w), 865 (vw), 838 (w), 815 (vw), 765 (w), 730 (w), 684 (w), 663 (vw), 621 (vw), 556 (w), 475 (w).

X-ray Crystallography. Intensity data for 1−3 were measured on a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL-97 program package. The positions of hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically (C−H bond fixed at 0.96 Å), assigned isotropic thermal parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent carbon atoms before the final cycle of refinement. Crystal data and a structure determination summary for 1−3 are listed in the Table . The selected bond lengths and angles for 1−3 are listed in the Table .

All empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL-97 program package. The positions of hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically (C-H bond fixed at 0.96 Å), assigned isotropic thermal parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent carbon atoms before the final cycle of refinement. Crystal data and a structure determination summary for 1-3 are listed in the Table . The selected bond lengths and angles for 1-3 are listed in the Table .

Syntheses. In the construction of metal−organic frameworks of dicarboxylate ligands, both the conventional solution method and the hydrothermal method are two synthetic routines usually adopted. In general, the conventional solution reactions of the transition metal ions and dicarboxylate ligands under ambient conditions usually produced complicated solid-state phases with various hydrate water contents. For example, many polymeric chains have been produced through bis-monodentate dicarboxylate ligands bridging pseudo square-planar M(H2O)4. However, a hydrothermal reaction not only can enhance metal−ligand interactions rather than metal−water coordination, and finally result in new extended coordination solids, but also can produce metastable compounds, which may not be accessible by the conventional method, to promote crystal growth since the nature and temperature of the hydrothermal fluid can be varied over a wide range. Thus, both the conventional solution method and hydrothermal synthetic method have an excellent intercomplementarity for the preparation of metal−organic complexes with different structures and functions.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

 Syntheses. In the construction of metal-organic frameworks of dicarboxylate ligands, both the conventional solution method and the hydrothermal method are two synthetic routines usually adopted. In general, the conventional solution reactions of the transition metal ions and dicarboxylate ligands under ambient conditions usually produced complicated solid-state phases with various hydrate water contents. For example, many polymeric chains have been produced through bis-monodentate dicarboxylate ligands bridging pseudo square-planar M(H2O)4. However, a hydrothermal reaction not only can enhance metal-ligand interactions rather than metal-water coordination, and finally result in new extended coordination solids, but also can produce metastable compounds, which may not be accessible by the conventional method, to promote crystal growth since the nature and temperature of the hydrothermal fluid can be varied over a wide range.  Thus, both the conventional solution method and hydrothermal synthetic method have an excellent intercomplementarity for the preparation of metal-organic complexes with different structures and functions.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of H2dpa and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O produced a one-dimensional chain polymer consisting of paddle-wheel tetracarboxylate dicopper(II) units. Obviously, to obtain a helical chain consisting of pseudo square-planar Cu(H2O)4 bridged dpa, which is similar to [M(H2O)4(dpa)] n (M = Co, Ni), the conventional solution method should be adopted. The reaction of H2dpa and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O in the presence of NaOH in MeOH/H2O at room temperature afforded a desirable helical complex 1. When introducing the neutral bridging ligands, 4,4‘-bipy and dpe, into the reaction system, an uncharacterized precipitate insoluble in any common solvents was obtained. It was apparent that the hydrothermal reaction should be employed to obtain extended structural motifs based on Cu−dpa helical chains. The hydrothermal reactions of 4,4‘-bipy and dpe with H2dpa and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O in the presence of NaOH afforded two novel three-dimensional structures composed of Cu−dpa helical chains bridged by 4,4‘-bipy and dpe, respectively (Scheme ); moreover, as the length of organic spacer in neutral bridging ligand increases, interpenetration has been adopted in 3 to avoid the formation of large open channels or cavities.
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of H2dpa and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O produced a one-dimensional chain polymer consisting of paddle-wheel tetracarboxylate dicopper(II) units. Obviously, to obtain a helical chain consisting of pseudo square-planar Cu(H2O)4 bridged dpa, which is similar to [M(H2O)4(dpa)] n  (M = Co, Ni), the conventional solution method should be adopted. The reaction of H2dpa and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O in the presence of NaOH in MeOH/H2O at room temperature afforded a desirable helical complex 1. When introducing the neutral bridging ligands, 4,4‘-bipy and dpe, into the reaction system, an uncharacterized precipitate insoluble in any common solvents was obtained. It was apparent that the hydrothermal reaction should be employed to obtain extended structural motifs based on Cu-dpa helical chains. The hydrothermal reactions of 4,4‘-bipy and dpe with H2dpa and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O in the presence of NaOH afforded two novel three-dimensional structures composed of Cu-dpa helical chains bridged by 4,4‘-bipy and dpe, respectively (Scheme ); moreover, as the length of organic spacer in neutral bridging ligand increases, interpenetration has been adopted in 3 to avoid the formation of large open channels or cavities.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of complexes 1−3 were performed on polycrystalline samples in a nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, the weight loss of 18.97% from 70 to 180 °C is equivalent to the loss of four coordinated water molecules [4H2O/Cu(H2O)4(dpa), cacld:  19.16%]; the second weight of 58.92% is achieved from 200 to 520 °C, the residue of 21.65% above 520 °C in 1 corresponds to the expected CuO values (21.15%). Complexes 2 and 3 show similar thermal stability; there was no chemical decomposition up to 260 °C, and a most significant weight loss occurs in the range from 260 and 500 °C, which suggests the samples decompose to copper(II) oxide. Considering the formation of a stoichiometric amount of CuO, this conclusion is supported by 18.16 and 16.97% of the residues at 500 °C for 2 and 3, respectively, which are closed to the expected values (17.29% for 2 and 16.36% for 3), respectively.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of complexes 1-3 were performed on polycrystalline samples in a nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, the weight loss of 18.97% from 70 to 180 °C is equivalent to the loss of four coordinated water molecules [4H2O/Cu(H2O)4(dpa), cacld: 19.16%]; the second weight of 58.92% is achieved from 200 to 520 °C, the residue of 21.65% above 520 °C in 1 corresponds to the expected CuO values (21.15%). Complexes 2 and 3 show similar thermal stability; there was no chemical decomposition up to 260 °C, and a most significant weight loss occurs in the range from 260 and 500 °C, which suggests the samples decompose to copper(II) oxide. Considering the formation of a stoichiometric amount of CuO, this conclusion is supported by 18.16 and 16.97% of the residues at 500 °C for 2 and 3, respectively, which are closed to the expected values (17.29% for 2 and 16.36% for 3), respectively.

elements.content: Structural Description. [Cu(H 2 O) 4 (dpa)] n (1). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 is a one-dimensional helical chain consisting of pseudo square-planar Cu(H2O)4 bridged dpa. As shown in Figure a, CuII center shows a slightly distorted octahedral geometry with four water molecules in the equatorial basal plane and two oxygen atoms from different dpa at the axial positions [O(11)−Cu−O(21A) 174.2(2)°]. CuII is coplanar with four coordinated water molecules and lies in the center of the equatorial plane. The bond distances of Cu−OH2O and cis angles of OH2O−Cu−OH2O lie in the ranges of 2.153(6)−2.324(10) Å and 87.5(2)−92.2(2)°, respectively. The Cu−Ocoo bond distances of 1.957(5) and 1.965(5) Å suggest a slightly compressed octahedron. Dpa in a bis-monodentate fashion bridges two CuII forming a one-dimensional helical chain (Figure b). The shortest and the next shortest Cu···Cu distances within a chain are 5.043 and 7.632 Å, respectively, which are similar to those in helical complexes [M(dpa)(H2O)4] n [M = Co(II), Ni(II)]. The latter distance defines the pitch of the helix. The geometry of dpa in 1 is similar to those in H2dpa and [M(dpa)(H2O)4] n . The carboxylate groups are out of the plane of correspondingly linking phenyl rings, with the dihedral angles between them being 26.7 and 44.5°. The dramatic twists between two phenyl rings and between two carboxylate groups in dpa are observed with the dihedral angles between them being 89.3 and 86.5°, respectively, which are approximately perpendicular to each other. The combination of these twists results in the formation of the helical chain. It is noteworthy that the key structural feature in 1 is a one-dimensional helix consisting of pseudo square-planar Cu(H2O)4 bridged dpa, but some flexible dicarboxylate ligands, such as succinate, and fumarate, link M(H2O)4 into linear chains, which suggests the twists of dpa are responsible for the formation of the helical chain. The hydrogen-bonding interactions between two water molecules [Ow1···Ow1i 2.701(16) Å; symmetry code:  2 − x, 2 − y, 1 − z] as well as between one water molecule and one uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom of dpa [Ow3-H···O12ii 2.648(7) Å; symmetry code:  2 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z] extend the helical chain to generate a two-dimensional layer structure (Figure c). The nearest Cu···Cu separation of the adjacent helical chains is 5.882 Å.
elements.clean_text: Structural Description. [Cu(H  2  O)  4  (dpa)]   n    (1). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 is a one-dimensional helical chain consisting of pseudo square-planar Cu(H2O)4 bridged dpa. As shown in Figure a, CuII center shows a slightly distorted octahedral geometry with four water molecules in the equatorial basal plane and two oxygen atoms from different dpa at the axial positions [O(11)-Cu-O(21A) 174.2(2)°]. CuII is coplanar with four coordinated water molecules and lies in the center of the equatorial plane. The bond distances of Cu-OH2O and cis angles of OH2O-Cu-OH2O lie in the ranges of 2.153(6)-2.324(10) Å and 87.5(2)-92.2(2)°, respectively. The Cu-Ocoo bond distances of 1.957(5) and 1.965(5) Å suggest a slightly compressed octahedron. Dpa in a bis-monodentate fashion bridges two CuII forming a one-dimensional helical chain (Figure b). The shortest and the next shortest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances within a chain are 5.043 and 7.632 Å, respectively, which are similar to those in helical complexes [M(dpa)(H2O)4] n  [M = Co(II), Ni(II)]. The latter distance defines the pitch of the helix. The geometry of dpa in 1 is similar to those in H2dpa and [M(dpa)(H2O)4] n . The carboxylate groups are out of the plane of correspondingly linking phenyl rings, with the dihedral angles between them being 26.7 and 44.5°. The dramatic twists between two phenyl rings and between two carboxylate groups in dpa are observed with the  dihedral angles between them being 89.3 and 86.5°, respectively, which are approximately perpendicular to each other. The combination of these twists results in the formation of the helical chain. It is noteworthy that the key structural feature in 1 is a one-dimensional helix consisting of pseudo square-planar Cu(H2O)4 bridged dpa, but some flexible dicarboxylate ligands, such as succinate, and fumarate, link M(H2O)4 into linear chains, which suggests the twists of dpa are responsible for the formation of the helical chain. The hydrogen-bonding interactions between two water molecules [Ow1⋅⋅⋅Ow1i 2.701(16) Å; symmetry code: 2 - x, 2 - y, 1 - z] as well as between one water molecule and one uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom of dpa [Ow3-H⋅⋅⋅O12ii 2.648(7) Å; symmetry code: 2 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z] extend the helical chain to generate a two-dimensional layer structure (Figure c). The nearest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation of the adjacent helical chains is 5.882 Å.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP drawing of1, drawn with displacement ellipsoids at the 30% probablility. (b) View of one-dimensional helical chain in 1. (c) Packing structure along the b-axis in 1 showing the hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adjacent helical chains.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) ORTEP drawing of1, drawn with displacement ellipsoids at the 30% probablility. (b) View of one-dimensional helical chain in 1. (c) Packing structure along the b-axis in 1 showing the hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adjacent helical chains.

elements.content: [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n (2). 2 is a three-dimensional polymer composed of Cu−dpa helical chains bridged by 4,4‘-bipy. As shown in Figure a, each CuII center is in a square-planar geometry by coordinating to two trans-pyridine nitrogen atoms of different 4,4‘-bipy and two trans-carboxylate oxygen atoms of different dpa ligands with cis-angles ranging from 89.38(10) to 90.62(10)°. The bond distances of Cu−Npy and Cu−Ocoo are 2.042(3) and 1.928(2) Å, respectively, which are typical values for Cu−Npy and Cu−Ocoo coordination distances. Dpa acts as a bis-monodentate ligand, the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 77.5°, the carboxylate groups are slightly out of the plane of correspondingly linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angles between them being 31.5°. A dramatic twisting is observed between two carboxylate groups in dpa with the dihedral angle between them being 84.5°. The combination of these twists results in the formation of a Cu−dpa helical chain. The shortest Cu···Cu distance and the distance of helical pitch within a chain are 5.713 and 11.425 Å, respectively, which are larger than those in 1, revealing that 4,4‘-bipy has a great effect on the helical framework. The exo-bidentate 4,4‘-bipy ligands link the adjacent helical chains together to construct a three- dimensional framework (Figure b). Two pyridyl rings in 4,4‘-bipy are coplanar. The Cu···Cu distance along the μ-4,4‘-bipy is 11.161 Å, which is slightly shorter than those in helical pitch but longer than the nearest Cu···Cu distance of 10.237 Å in different helical chains.
elements.clean_text: [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)]   n   (2). 2 is a three-dimensional polymer composed of Cu-dpa helical chains bridged by 4,4‘-bipy. As shown in Figure a, each CuII center is in a square-planar geometry by coordinating to two trans-pyridine nitrogen atoms of different 4,4‘-bipy and two trans-carboxylate oxygen atoms of different dpa ligands with cis-angles ranging from 89.38(10) to 90.62(10)°. The bond distances of Cu-Npy and Cu-Ocoo are 2.042(3) and 1.928(2) Å, respectively, which are typical values for Cu-Npy and Cu-Ocoo coordination distances. Dpa acts as a bis-monodentate ligand, the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 77.5°, the carboxylate groups are slightly out of the plane of correspondingly linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angles between them being 31.5°. A dramatic twisting is observed between two carboxylate groups in dpa with the dihedral angle between them being 84.5°. The combination of these twists results in the formation of a Cu-dpa helical chain. The shortest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance and the distance of helical pitch within a chain are 5.713 and 11.425 Å, respectively, which are larger than those in 1, revealing that 4,4‘-bipy has a great effect on the helical framework. The exo-bidentate 4,4‘-bipy ligands link the adjacent helical chains together to construct a three- dimensional framework (Figure b). Two pyridyl rings in 4,4‘-bipy are coplanar. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance along the μ-4,4‘-bipy is 11.161 Å, which is slightly shorter than those in helical pitch but longer than the nearest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 10.237 Å in different helical chains.

(b) Packing structure along the c-axis in 3 showing the dpa-Cu helical chains bridged by dpe. (c) The 2-fold interpenetration in 3 viewed along the c-axis with partial atoms omitted for clarity.

elements.content: [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n (3). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 3 is a 2-fold-interpenetration three-dimensional polymer comprising Cu−dpa helical chains bridged by dpe. As shown in Figure a, the CuII center is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different dpe and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different dpa in a trans arrangement with cis-angles ranging from 88.9(2) to 92.4(2)°. However, the Cu−O(2) distance of 2.575(2) Å suggests a nonnegligible interaction with an uncoordinated oxygen of the bis-monodentate dpa ligand, which may be described as a semi-chelating coordination mode. Hence, the CuII center may be also regarded as a square-pyramidal geometry. Similar to 2, the bridging dpa ligands link CuII centers into a helical chain with the shortest Cu···Cu distance and the distance of helical pitch within the chain being 8.070 and 16.022 Å, respectively, which are larger than those in 2. The dihedral angles between two phenyl rings and between two carboxylate groups in a dpa are 84.5 and 73.4°, respectively. However, the distortion angles between carboxylate groups and correspondingly linking phenyl rings are 21.4 and 32.3°, which are comparable with those in 1 and 2. As shown in Figure b, trans-dpe ligands link the adjacent Cu−dpa helical chains into a three-dimensional structure. The Cu···Cu distance based on dpe is 13.434 Å. It should be emphasized that longer helical pitches and dpe ligands have resulted in the formation of larger void space in the three-dimensional framework, which greatly exceeds that required to accommodate the guest molecules in the reaction system. Thus, instead of forming an open, microporous structure, the potential voids are filled via mutual interpenetration of two identical three-dimensional frameworks.
elements.clean_text: [Cu(dpe)(dpa)]   n    (3). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 3 is a 2-fold-interpenetration three-dimensional polymer comprising Cu-dpa helical chains bridged by dpe. As shown in Figure a, the CuII center is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different dpe and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different dpa in a trans arrangement with cis-angles ranging from 88.9(2) to 92.4(2)°. However, the Cu-O(2) distance of 2.575(2) Å suggests a nonnegligible interaction with an uncoordinated oxygen of the bis-monodentate dpa ligand, which may be described as a semi-chelating coordination mode. Hence, the CuII center may be also regarded as a square-pyramidal geometry. Similar to 2, the bridging dpa ligands link CuII centers into a helical chain with the shortest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance and the distance of helical pitch within the chain being 8.070 and 16.022 Å, respectively, which are larger than those in 2. The dihedral angles between two phenyl rings and between two carboxylate groups in a dpa are 84.5 and 73.4°, respectively. However, the distortion angles between carboxylate groups and correspondingly linking phenyl rings are 21.4 and 32.3°, which are comparable with those in 1 and 2. As shown in Figure b, trans-dpe ligands link the adjacent Cu-dpa helical chains into a three-dimensional structure. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance based on dpe is 13.434 Å. It should be emphasized that longer helical pitches and dpe ligands have resulted in the formation of larger void space in the three-dimensional framework, which greatly exceeds that required to accommodate the guest molecules in the reaction system. Thus, instead of forming an open, microporous structure, the potential voids are filled via mutual interpenetration of two identical three-dimensional frameworks.

elements.content: A one-dimensional CuII helical complex and two three-dimensional CuII frameworks consisting of discrete Cu−dpa helical chains have been prepared by the conventional solution method and the hydrothermal method, respectively. The research shows that the helical complexes can be synthesized through trial and error of organic ligands containing appropriate coordination sites linked by a spacer with specific positional orientations; moreover, the novel extended networks can be obtained by using neutral exo-bidentate ligands bridging helical chains.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A one-dimensional CuII helical complex and two three-dimensional CuII frameworks consisting of discrete Cu-dpa helical chains have been prepared by the conventional solution method and the hydrothermal method, respectively. The research shows that the helical complexes can be synthesized through trial and error of organic ligands containing appropriate coordination sites linked by a spacer with specific positional orientations; moreover, the novel extended networks can be obtained by using neutral exo-bidentate ligands bridging helical chains.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of [Cu(H 2 O) 4 (dpa)] n (1). A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was added slowly to a stirring solution of H2dpa (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL), and then 1 mol L-1 NaOH aqueous solution was added dropwise to the reaction mixture until a slight amount of precipitate was formed. The precipitate was filtered off, and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for one week; the blue crystals were produced. Yield:  0.09 g (48%). Anal. Calcd. for C14H16CuO8 (375.81):  C, 44.74; H, 4.26%. Found:  C, 44.69; H, 4.28%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3619 (m), 3435 (m), 3180 (w), 1610 (s), 1600 (s), 1578 (s), 1538 (s), 1495 (m), 1472 (m), 1444 (m), 1397 (vs, br), 1367 (s), 1281 (w), 1271 (w), 1243 (w), 1151 (w), 1109 (vw), 1094 (vw), 1049 (vw), 1006 (w), 989 (vw), 958 (vw), 884 (vw), 830 (m), 813 (w), 771 (m), 679 (m), 662 (m), 622 (w), 588 (vw), 574 (w), 476 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(dpa)] n (2). A mixture of H2dpa (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), and NaOH (0.03 g, 0.75 mmol) with a molar ratio of about 2:2:2:3 in H2O (15.0 mL) was sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 160 °C for 72 h, and then the reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 24 h. A larger amount of dark-blue crystals were obtained and collected by filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield:  0.14 g (61%). Anal. Calcd. for C24H16CuN2O4 (459.92):  C, 62.67; H, 3.48; N, 6.09%. Found:  C, 62.63; H, 3.51; N, 6.07%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3440 (vw, br), 1606 (s), 1584 (s), 1560 (m), 1535 (m), 1488 (m), 1403 (vs, br), 1367 (s), 1327 (m), 1220 (w), 1162 (w), 1148 (w), 1107 (vw), 1094 (vw), 1071 (w), 1046 (vw), 1008 (vw), 960 (vw), 853 (vw), 843 (w), 822 (m), 772 (m), 721 (m), 681 (w), 662 (vw), 641 (w), 590 (vw), 556 (w), 485 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu(dpe)(dpa)] n (3). The procedure is similar to the synthesis of 2 except that dpe (0.09 g, 0.5 mmol) was used instead of 4,4‘-bipy. Yield:  0.18 g (74%). Anal. Calcd. for C26H18CuN2O4 (485.96):  C, 64.26; H, 3.70; N, 5.76%. Found:  C, 64.22; H, 3.71; N, 5.74%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3440 (vw, br), 1610 (s), 1586 (s), 1566 (m), 1556 (m), 1502 (m), 1402 (vs, br), 1347 (s), 1298 (w), 1251 (w), 1219 (w), 1205 (w), 1147 (w), 1102 (vw), 1069 (vw), 1047 (vw), 1025 (w), 987 (w), 969 (w), 865 (vw), 838 (w), 815 (vw), 765 (w), 730 (w), 684 (w), 663 (vw), 621 (vw), 556 (w), 475 (w).

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of complexes 1−3 were performed on polycrystalline samples in a nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, the weight loss of 18.97% from 70 to 180 °C is equivalent to the loss of four coordinated water molecules [4H2O/Cu(H2O)4(dpa), cacld:  19.16%]; the second weight of 58.92% is achieved from 200 to 520 °C, the residue of 21.65% above 520 °C in 1 corresponds to the expected CuO values (21.15%). Complexes 2 and 3 show similar thermal stability; there was no chemical decomposition up to 260 °C, and a most significant weight loss occurs in the range from 260 and 500 °C, which suggests the samples decompose to copper(II) oxide. Considering the formation of a stoichiometric amount of CuO, this conclusion is supported by 18.16 and 16.97% of the residues at 500 °C for 2 and 3, respectively, which are closed to the expected values (17.29% for 2 and 16.36% for 3), respectively.

Complexes 2 and 3 show similar thermal stability; there was no chemical decomposition up to 260 °C, and a most significant weight loss occurs in the range from 260 and 500 °C, which suggests the samples decompose to copper(II) oxide. Considering the formation of a stoichiometric amount of CuO, this conclusion is supported by 18.16 and 16.97% of the residues at 500 °C for 2 and 3, respectively, which are closed to the expected values (17.29% for 2 and 16.36% for 3), respectively.
